Date of Assessment:   2021 - 11 - 15  Date of Report:   2021 - 11 - 18  THERAPIST   QUALIFICATIONS:  Mr. Ferland   is an Occupational Therapist with over   23   years of experience.   His professional  practice began in 1998 when he graduated Magna Cum Laude from the University of Ottawa and  launched himself in the world of private business. Over the years,   he   has provided services to the  automobile insurance and   legal communities as well the WSIB, Veterans Affairs and the Long -  Term Disability sector.  Mr. Ferland   has extensive experience working with individuals suffering from catastrophic  injuries. He provides assessment and treatment services as a primary Occu pational Therapist as  well as a Case Manager for individuals who sustained traumatic brain injuries, spinal cord injuries  and amputations.   He also has extensive experience working with individuals who have been  deemed to meet the catastrophic threshold on   the basis of psychological and/or psychiatric  impairments.  Over his years of working with individuals injured in motor vehicle accidents,   Mr. Ferland  developed a strong interest in the field of mental health, focussed on functional reactivation for  injur ed individuals suffering from depression,   anxiety,   and posttraumatic stress.   His clinical

Date of Report:   2021 - 11 - 18  ______________________________________________________________________________  Jawad   Abdul   Hussein   Claim #:   1348323   Page   2   of   19  acumen has led him to be qualified as an Expert in his field by the Ontario Superior Court of  Justice.  PURPOSE OF REFERRAL :  Mr.   Abdul Hussein was referred to Ferland & Associates Rehabilitation Inc. by his legal  representative Mr. Frank McNally of McNally Gervan Law Firm in order to complete an In - Home  Assessment   as well as to provide urgent treatment interventions. Mr. Abdul Huss ein was found in  a state of acute emotional distress   at the time of referral and a number of treatment sessions were  provided   leading to the completion of this In - Home Assessment. A number of referrals were made  by this therapist to intervene in Mr. Abdul   Hussein’s   poor emotional state and to provide him with  a circle of care   from a multi - disciplinary team of professionals.  SUMMARY OF FINDINGS:  Mr. Abdul Hussein is a   23 - year - old   man who was involved in a motor vehicle accident on January  14, 2018 in which he sustained the following injuries:  •   Sprain and strain of lumbar spine and ankle  •   Whiplash associated disorder  •   Concussion with post   concussional   syndrome  •   Anxiety Disorder, unspecified  •   Somatic Symptom Disorder  •   Makor Depressive Disorder  Almost   4 years post - accident, Mr. Abdul Hussein continues to struggle with an array of physical  emotional and cognitive   symptoms which have led to a significant de terioration in his mental  health.   In recent weeks, Mr. Abdul Hussein was taken twice to the hospital ER (once by  ambulance) as a result of uncontrollable anxiety leading to a severe panic attack.   Mr. Abdul  Hussein presented with suicidal   ideation and not ed that he no longer wishes to live.   He has  experienced significant losses as a result of his   injuries,   and he fears for the future   given how his  symptoms do not appear to be improving. He finds his cognitive symptoms particularly troubling  a s his   short - term   memory, concentration, focus, problem   solving,   and multi - tasking have all been  deeply impacted.  Prior to the s u bject motor vehicle accident, Mr. Abdul Hussein was   working as a self - employed  restaurant eur, operating a pizza and Greek food restaur ant. He worked long hours, up to   12 - hour  days, six days per week.   In his limited time off, he would go out   for dinner with friends, got to  the gym 3 -   4 times per week and socialize in various   locales. He noted that he was a hard worker  and enjoyed build ing   and running his business with his father.  Following the subject motor vehicle accident, Mr. Abdul Hussein experienced an array of physic al,  cognitive,   and emotional symptoms which persist to this day. By his account, potentially due to a  lack of treatment over the last two years, his condition has become worse resulting in significant  increases in his emotional distress and suicidal thoughts.   Communic ation with his father has

Date of Report:   2021 - 11 - 18  ______________________________________________________________________________  Jawad   Abdul   Hussein   Claim #:   1348323   Page   3   of   19  confirmed a pattern of   panic attacks and   periods of emotional distress which Mr. Abdul Hussein  is ill - equipped to manage. He has a limited array of coping strategies and is finding prescription  medication ineffective in   maintaini ng a calm disposure.   He has been recently assessed by the  Royal Ottawa Hospital Mood Disorder Clinic and will be obtaining psychiatric support in tandem  with the multi - disciplinary team which is now being activated in his care.   This therapist has  fostere d the following referrals to support Mr. Abdul Hussein at this critical time in his recovery:  •   Ricci & Associates   –   Mr. Abdul Hussein has been referred to Dr. Ricci for a psychological  assessment which was originally scheduled for January of 2022.   Given M r. Abdul  Hussein’s   deteriorating mental health, this therapist communicated with the offices of Ricci  & Associates in order to seek emergency care in advance of completing the assessment.  This has been achieved and the   assessment has been moved to early - D ecember   of 2021  with   treatment interventions to begin imminently.  •   Apollo Physical Therapy   –   This therapist communicated with Apollo Physical Therapy in  order to   have Mr .   Abdul Hussein resume care.   He has undergone a re - assessment and  resumed   Chiropractic Care with Dr. Vikas Dhawan .  •   Fleming Fitness   –   Mr. Abdul Hussein was found to have no physical outlet and   engaged in  limited   physical activity. In order to assist with conditioning and to help reduce his anxiety  levels, a referral for Yoga and   Kinesiology was facilitated by this therapist.   Both  treatments have been approved by the insurer.  •   Opticalm   –   Mr. Abdul Hussein has noted significant issues with light sensitivity as a result  of his persistent concussive symptoms. He has been referred to   Opticalm for a visual stress  assessment to be followed by a prescription for   tinted eyeglasses.  •   Ottawa Distress Line   –   Mr. Abdul Hussein has been provided with the number for the  Ottawa Distress Line to provide him with an alternative when he wishes to   speak with  someone outside of his household during peri o ds of distress where   family members   may  not be available.  At this juncture, Mr. Abdul Hussein is readily engaged in treatment with this therapist and has  been highly responsive to the interventions p rovided to date.   He is reporting a sense of  optimism with the   newly forming team of professionals and   confirmed his willingness to  engage in all therapies proposed by thi s   therapist.   He continues to benefit from Attendant Care  provided by his   family to assist with managing his emotional outbursts where he loses control  of his anxiety , unfolding into recurrent and frequent panic attacks. It is expected that the Mood  Disorder clinic   psychiatric assessment will lead to changes in his medication t o assist him in  better   navigating the next steps in his rehabilitation.  Mr. Abdul   Hussein   has not been able to return to work post - accident, having reportedly  attempted to work two days and being unable to cope with the demands of his employment.  His fa ther   has   since sold his restaurant and he has no means of gainful employment at this  juncture. He relies on his mother to complete the few housekeeping tasks he used to manage  pre - accident   as he finds himself unable to   find the motivation to   contribute at   this time,   He  has largely interrupted all of his leisure activities and is mostly isolating in his home with  periodic visits to his father’s barber shop in an attempt to socialize.

Assistive Devices:  There are no assistive devices currently recommended to   assist in Mr. Abdul Hussein’s  rehabilitation.   Consideration for assistive devices will be given during the delivery of OT  treatment sessions   proposed below. IE Paper Review Psychology by Dr Schmidt dated July 22, 2019  PRE - ACCIDENT MEDICAL HISTORY:  Mr. Abdul Hussein   reported being in excellent   physical and mental health prior to the subject  motor vehicle accident. He was   a   young restaurant owner working   65   –   75 hours per week. He  had an active social life, would go out with friends dining in restaurants. He attended the gym   3   –  4 time s per week and was feeling fulfilled.   He denied the presence of any pre - existing medical  conditions or prior injuries which would impact his course of recovery or his clinical presentation  during this assessment.  MECHANISM OF INJURY:  Mr. Abdul Hussein   reported having little recollection of the accident.   He recalls hearing a big  bang and then losing consciousness.   From reading   reports   from other providers , he   believes he  was t - boned   by another vehicle . He is u nsure if he hit his head. Paramedics came to the   scene,  and he was taken to the Ottawa   General Hospital .   His first recollection   was being tended to by  paramedics and fearing for his life. He was not oriented to time and place.   “I   was not able to see  anything,   everything felt black in my head ” .   He was assessed at the ER and released later that  evening with instructions to see hi s family physician.   He reports symptoms of dizziness and  nausea for months following the MVA. There were sessions where Mr. Abdul Hussein was completely overwhelmed with  anxiety and experiencing the beginnings of a panic attack.
